title: Don't Look Left: A Diary of Genocide
author: Saif, Atef Abu
my rating: 1 of 5 stars2 of 5 stars3 of 5 stars4 of 5 stars5 of 5 starsadd to shelves
review: A book where the same things happen every day: get up search for food (increasingly hard to come by); pull relatives and friends out of the rubble (alA book where the same things happen every day: get up search for food (increasingly hard to come by); pull relatives and friends out of the rubble (alive if you're lucky); avoid if you can the Israeli bombs, bullets and tanks; try to get warm with one blanket in a tent; wash when you can (rarely, no water available); march (or push wheelchairs of the injured and maimed) to the next designated safe place for Gazans only to find it unsafe; try and communicate with others and find out what the world is saying about the conflict while the internet and power is cut; try to follow the logic of the IDF - why do they bomb schools, hospitals, refuges, kill aid workers and people doing what they were told to do? Why make random Gazans strip to their underwear and stand in the same place for hours? One of the writer's nieces loses her legs and a hand, her sister, her only carer, cannot cope and ends up in an Egyptian mental hospital. Many of his family and colleagues (he's a reporter/playwright and novelist) die as he writes a diary about his time there. After 85 days (on 30th Dec) he and his son Yasser are allowed to leave and are able to get to Egypt, but he feels extremely guilty about what he has left behind. His family are used to exile, having been forcibly removed from Jaffa in 1948 (before he was born) and have suffered earlier invasions (eg 2014), but this one is the longest, the worst so far (at the time of publication 15,000 dead, now double that). A terribly depressing but important document, a testimony and witness statement to unconscionable death and destruction....more

review: I would read 60-70 pages of this transported like a dream, the transparent prose so good and then i would be glitched out of it by a deep conversationI would read 60-70 pages of this transported like a dream, the transparent prose so good and then i would be glitched out of it by a deep conversation on quantum physics or the rifle bores possibly used in the Kennedy assassination of 1963. Well beyond my ken. Took a while too, to get used to the schizophrenic sister's hallucinations (including the Thalidomide Kid and various circus performers crowded around her bed). But overall, a great read, again. title: This Is the Place to Be
author: Pawson, Lara
my rating: 1 of 5 stars2 of 5 stars3 of 5 stars4 of 5 stars5 of 5 starsadd to shelves
review: Powerful, fearless account of the author's years as a BBC foreign correspondent in Angola and elsewhere mixed with paragraphs on her childhood, her rePowerful, fearless account of the author's years as a BBC foreign correspondent in Angola and elsewhere mixed with paragraphs on her childhood, her relationship with her body and her peers and politics. The narrative is not straightforwardly chronological - instead it drifts from one topic to another but this seems to strengthen it (to me), like someone talking in a pub, albeit extremely articulately. She is often mistaken for a man (and Jamie Lee Curtis) and this leads her to discuss sexuality, gender roles etc. Her fearlessness is not only illustrated by her war experiences but also when she gets back to London and confronts burglars attempting to rob her neighbour. All in all an astonishing read, economically written (p130)....more

title: Seeing Red by Lina Meruane
author: Meruane, Lina
my rating: 1 of 5 stars2 of 5 stars3 of 5 stars4 of 5 stars5 of 5 starsadd to shelves
review: A Chilean woman living in New York goes near blind when both eyes start internal haemorrhaging. Acutely observed (!) interactions, sometimes minute byA Chilean woman living in New York goes near blind when both eyes start internal haemorrhaging. Acutely observed (!) interactions, sometimes minute by minute, between her and her lover, mother, doctor and doctor's assistant in various combinations (sometimes all at once). The prose has many beautiful touches (the nurse who strangled her wrist looking for a pulse). I'm a bit squeamish when it comes to eyes so the medical procedures and surgery - and aftermath - described made me squirm (brought to mind Dali's Chien d'Andalou). Exquisite detail. Not a good advert for Santiago (she returns there to family for a while) - everyone's freezing....more

author: Waddington, Ben

review: Christmas present. Excellent guide. Even though I've lived in Birmingham for more than forty years there was still a lot new to me. For example 'The EChristmas present. Excellent guide. Even though I've lived in Birmingham for more than forty years there was still a lot new to me. For example 'The Emergence of Women' tapestry in the ICC (International Convention Centre) which I've missed even though I must have walked through it a hundred times; and I didn't know (or perhaps had forgotten) the re-design of Victoria Square in the 90s was based around the theme of fecundity: even the benches - 'cut into the backs are distinctive silhouettes of spermatozoa, fertilising an egg at the centre of the bench'. A real eye-opener!...more

title: Innards: Stories
author: Makhene, Magogodi oaMphela
my rating: 1 of 5 stars2 of 5 stars3 of 5 stars4 of 5 stars5 of 5 starsadd to shelves
review: Took me a while to read these brilliant stories of South Africa (in particular Soweto) during apartheid and after (and before - the Boer War features)Took me a while to read these brilliant stories of South Africa (in particular Soweto) during apartheid and after (and before - the Boer War features), mainly because there are no concessions made to the 'general' reader: quite rightly. I had to read every story, every paragraph twice (and more), opening up my laptop to track down events and dialect and unusual words - haruspex anyone? Tachyons? Gatvol? Sjambok? It was worth it as the stories sliced into the communities depicted with skill and compassion. Along with horrific torture, rape and discrimination there was much comedy and fun to be had - eg an escaped bull, the pompousness of officials. Some soaring, beautiful writing. Fantastic stuff if you’re prepared for a sometimes difficult ride…...more

review: I know Malachi (we were in the same book (The Book of Birmingham, 2018)), and heard him read from this wonderful collection last week down in lovely DI know Malachi (we were in the same book (The Book of Birmingham, 2018)), and heard him read from this wonderful collection last week down in lovely Digbeth in a bar under the railway arches. These stories are full of humour and insight, especially when about office work/politics, young fatherhood, racism or how not to react when sent a box of limbs. There’s mystery here too, an unseen suicide from a railway platform, the grief that releases slowly after a child brother’s death. Beautiful prose as always....more
